body:
Understood, just saying my first impression was to use the highlighted
section containing these in reference to the declarations, if that section
starting with "these types are identical" were above the declarations there
would be no implication that it is in reference to the declarations.

I still don't understand the benefit of stating that a single thing is
identical to itself, it's like saying 0 = 0, I love go because it is more
simple and straightforward but somehow I feel like I'm missing out on some
magical thing here ... just saying :)

On Tue, Dec 9, 2014 at 1:36 PM, Robert Griesemer <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> []int is not a declaration (if it were it would declare a name, which
> would defeat the very purpose of this exposition) - []int is a type. It's
> worth mentioning that []int and a different []int are identical.
>
> The point of this section is to show which types are identical, some of
> which are constructed using types in the given declaration, and some of
> which are not.
>
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/golang/go/issues/9226#issuecomment-66333049>.
>
